     6→# Universal CV Data Ingestion & Organization
     7→
     8→Transforms unstructured career data into the portfolio's content structure, ready for variant generation and "hired-on-sight" presentation.
     9→
    10→## Input Directory
    11→
    12→**Drop all source files in `source-data/`** — this directory is gitignored.

    71→## Processing Workflow
    72→
    73→### Phase 0: Schema Understanding (MANDATORY FIRST STEP)
    74→
    75→**Objective**: Read and internalize the actual Zod schemas before writing ANY content.
    76→
    77→**CRITICAL**: This step MUST be completed before any file writes. Schema mismatches were the #1 source of validation errors in past runs.
    78→
    79→```bash
    80→# Always read the schema file first
    81→Read src/lib/schemas.ts
    82→```
    83→
    84→**Key Schema Constraints to Verify**:
    85→
    86→| Content Type | Field | Constraint |
    87→|-------------|-------|------------|
    88→| Skills | `skills` | `z.array(z.string())` — simple strings only, NOT objects |
    89→| Case Study Media | `type` | `z.enum(['blog', 'twitter', 'linkedin', 'video', 'article', 'slides'])` |
    90→| Testimonial | `featured` | `z.boolean()` — required, not optional |
    91→| Experience | `highlights` | `z.array(z.string())` — simple strings only |
    92→| Case Study CTA | `action` | `z.enum(['contact', 'calendly', 'linkedin'])` — only these 3 values |
    93→
    94→**Before writing any file, confirm**:
    95→1. ✅ Field types match schema exactly (string vs object vs array)
    96→2. ✅ Enum values are from the allowed set
    97→3. ✅ Required fields are present
    98→4. ✅ Optional fields use correct null/undefined handling

   102→### Phase 1: Data Discovery & Inventory
   103→
   104→**Objective**: Map all source files before processing.
   105→
   106→#### Step 1a: Check for Existing AI Summaries (HIGH PRIORITY)
   107→
   108→**Before parsing raw files**, look for existing AI-generated summaries or reviews. These are often more structured and save significant parsing time.
   109→
   110→```bash
   111→# Look for AI review files
   112→find source-data/ -name "*review*" -o -name "*summary*" -o -name "*gemini*" -o -name "*claude*" -o -name "*gpt*"
   113→
   114→# Check for structured exports
   115→find source-data/ -name "*.json" -o -name "*export*"
   116→```
   117→
   118→**If found**: Use as PRIMARY source, cross-reference with raw data for verification.
   119→
   120→#### Step 1b: Inventory Raw Sources
   121→
   122→```bash
   123→# For Obsidian vault
   124→find source-data/ -name "*.md" -type f | head -50
   125→
   126→# For zip archive (extract first)
   127→unzip -l source-data/*.zip | head -50
   128→
   129→# Categorize by type
   130→find source-data/ -type f \( -name "*.md" -o -name "*.csv" -o -name "*.txt" -o -name "*.json" \)
   131→```

   141→### Phase 2: Experience Enrichment
   142→
   143→For each work role, extract/synthesize:
   144→
   145→```yaml
   146→# Target: content/experience/index.yaml
   147→jobs:
   148→  - company: "Company Name"
   149→    role: "Job Title"
   150→    period: "YYYY – YYYY"
   151→    location: "City, State"
   152→    logo: "/images/logos/company.svg"  # Optional, nullable
   153→    url: "https://company.com"         # Company website - ALWAYS extract if available
   154→    highlights:
   155→      - "Achievement with specific metric (e.g., 15× revenue growth)"
   156→      - "Technical accomplishment with stack details"
   157→      - "Cross-functional impact with scope"
   158→      - "Decision/trade-off that shows judgment"
   159→      - "Scale indicator (users, transactions, team size)"
   160→    tags: ["Domain1", "Tech1", "Skill1"]
   161→```
   162→
   163→**Enrichment criteria**:
   164→- 3-4 highlights per role (focused, not exhaustive)
   165→- Specific metrics > vague claims (SMART: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant)
   166→- Technologies and methodologies named
   167→- Collaboration scope mentioned
   168→- Key decisions with trade-offs
   169→
   170→#### Product Links in Highlights (IMPORTANT)
   171→
   172→**Highlights support markdown links** — use `[Product Name](url)` to link to shipped products, docs, or proof.
   173→
   174→```yaml
   175→# Example with inline product links
   176→highlights:
   177→  - "Shipped [Advanced API](https://ankr.com/docs/advanced-api/) from 0→1, serving 1M+ daily requests"
   178→  - "Built [Xbox royalties blockchain](https://ey.com/case-study) achieving 99% faster processing"
   179→  - "Launched [Playground V2](https://play.flow.com/) improving developer onboarding by 60%"
   180→```
   181→
   182→**Link priority for highlights**:
   183→1. Live product/demo URLs (highest credibility)
   184→2. Official documentation
   185→3. NPM/PyPI package pages
   186→4. GitHub repos
   187→5. Case studies or press coverage
   188→
   189→**Why this matters**: Recruiters verify claims. A clickable link to a live product instantly validates the work is real.
   190→
   191→#### Link Extraction (IMPORTANT)
   192→
   193→**Always extract and verify company/project URLs** so viewers can quickly validate the work is real.
   194→
   195→**Sources for URLs**:
   196→1. Company websites mentioned in source docs
   197→2. LinkedIn company pages
   198→3. Product URLs, app store links
   199→4. GitHub repos, documentation sites
   200→5. Press releases, news articles
   201→
   202→**Link extraction process**:
   203→```bash
   204→# Search source files for URLs
   205→grep -oE 'https?://[^\s<>"]+' [SOURCE_FILES]
   206→
   207→# Common patterns to look for
   208→- "company.com", "startup.io", "project.xyz"
   209→- LinkedIn: linkedin.com/company/[name]
   210→- GitHub: github.com/[org]
   211→- Product Hunt, Crunchbase links
   212→```
   213→
   214→**Validation**:
   215→- Verify URL is still active (not 404)
   216→- Prefer official company domain over third-party
   217→- For defunct companies: use archive.org link or LinkedIn
   218→
   219→| Company Type | URL Priority |
   220→|-------------|--------------|
   221→| Active startup | Official website (e.g., mempools.com) |
   222→| Enterprise | Company careers/about page |
   223→| Acquired | Parent company or press release |
   224→| Defunct | LinkedIn or archive.org |
   225→
   226→#### Confidence Scoring for Experience Data
   227→
   228→Track extraction confidence for each data point:
   229→
   230→| Confidence | Criteria | Action |
   231→|------------|----------|--------|
   232→| ⬛⬛⬛ **High** | Exact quote from source, verified metric, named source | Use directly |
   233→| ⬛⬛⬜ **Medium** | Synthesized from multiple sources, approximated metric | Use with note |
   234→| ⬛⬜⬜ **Low** | Inferred, placeholder metric like "[X%]", uncertain date | Flag for user review |
   235→
   236→**Before writing experience file**:
   237→1. List all LOW confidence items for user confirmation
   238→2. Mark uncertain metrics with `[VERIFY]` prefix in draft
   239→3. Only write after user confirms or provides corrections
   240→

   242→
   243→```yaml

   250→    location: string     # Required
   251→    logo: string | null  # Optional
   252→    url: string | null   # Optional - but ALWAYS try to populate!
   253→    highlights: string[] # Required: array of STRINGS (not objects!)
   254→    tags: string[]       # Required

   298→
   299→### Phase 4: Testimonial Extraction
   300→
   301→#### Distinguishing Personal vs Project Testimonials (CRITICAL)
   302→
   303→**Personal testimonials** (USE these):
   304→- About the individual: "Working with [Name]...", "[Name] is exceptional at..."
   305→- Collaboration focused: "...a pleasure to work with", "...always delivered"
   306→- Skill endorsements: "...best product manager I've worked with"
   307→- Growth observations: "...grew from... to..."
   308→
   309→**Project testimonials** (DO NOT use as personal):
   310→- About the project/product: "The blockchain solution transformed..."
   311→- Company endorsements: "Microsoft's approach to..."
   312→- Generic team praise: "The team delivered..."
   313→
   314→#### Detection Heuristics
   315→
   316→**High-confidence personal testimonial signals**:
   317→```
   318→✅ Contains person's name + positive verb: "[Name] led", "[Name] designed"
   319→✅ Uses "I" + relationship: "I worked with", "I hired", "I managed"
   320→✅ Personal qualities: "collaborative", "thoughtful", "proactive"
   321→✅ Recommendation language: "I recommend", "would hire again"
   322→✅ Source: LinkedIn recommendation, performance review
   323→```
   324→
   325→**Low-confidence / Project quote signals**:
   326→```
   327→⚠️ No personal name mentioned
   328→⚠️ Focuses on deliverable, not person
   329→⚠️ Source: press release, case study, marketing material
   330→⚠️ Generic praise: "great work", "successful project"
   331→```
   332→
   333→#### Search Patterns for Testimonials
   334→
   335→```bash
   336→# Phrases indicating personal testimonials
   337→grep -i "working with \[name\]" [SOURCE]
   338→grep -i "I recommend" [SOURCE]
   339→grep -i "pleasure to work" [SOURCE]
   340→grep -i "\[name\] is" [SOURCE]
   341→grep -i "one of the best" [SOURCE]
   342→
   343→# LinkedIn recommendation patterns
   344→grep -i "I had the opportunity" [SOURCE]
   345→grep -i "I've had the pleasure" [SOURCE]
   346→```
   347→
   348→#### Testimonial Quality Checklist
   349→
   350→Before including a testimonial:
   351→- [ ] Is it about the PERSON, not just the project?
   352→- [ ] Does it include specific details (not generic praise)?
   353→- [ ] Can the source be verified (LinkedIn, named author)?
   354→- [ ] Is the author's relationship clear (manager, peer, report)?
   355→
   356→```yaml
   357→# Target: content/testimonials/index.yaml
   358→testimonials:
   359→  - quote: >
   360→      Full testimonial text with specific details about
   361→      collaboration, impact, or skills demonstrated.
   362→    author: "Full Name"  # Or "Engineering Lead" if anonymized
   363→    initials: "FN"
   364→    role: "Their Role"
   365→    company: "Company Name"
   366→    avatar: null  # Or path to image
   367→    featured: true  # Required boolean - for prominent display
   368→```
   369→
   370→#### Gap Handling
   371→
   372→If no valid personal testimonials found:
   373→1. **Flag as HIGH priority gap** in gap analysis
   374→2. Suggest manual follow-up actions:
   375→   - Export LinkedIn recommendations
   376→   - Request recommendations from past colleagues
   377→   - Check old emails for praise snippets
   378→3. **DO NOT fabricate** or use project quotes as personal testimonials
   379→
   380→### Phase 5: Skills Taxonomy
   381→
   382→#### CRITICAL: Schema Constraint
   383→
   384→**The skills schema expects SIMPLE STRINGS, not objects!**
   385→
   386→```yaml
   387→# ❌ WRONG - This will fail validation
   388→categories:
   389→  - name: "Technical Leadership"
   390→    skills:
   391→      - name: "Platform Architecture"
   392→        level: "expert"
   393→        evidence: "..."
   394→
   395→# ✅ CORRECT - Simple string array

   397→  - name: "Technical Leadership"
   398→    skills:
   399→      - "Platform Architecture"
   400→      - "API Design"
   401→      - "System Integration"

   403→
   404→#### Preserving Evidence (Workaround)

   413→      # Evidence: Designed multi-client validator infra at Anchorage
   414→      - "Platform Architecture"
   415→      # Evidence: Shipped Ankr Advanced APIs, 1M+ daily requests
   416→      - "API Design"
   417→
   418→  - name: "Web3 & Blockchain"
   419→    skills:
   420→      # Evidence: First smart contract at Microsoft (2016)
   421→      - "Ethereum"
   422→      # Evidence: ETF-grade validator provisioning
   423→      - "Staking Infrastructure"
   424→```
   425→
   426→#### Pre-Validation Check
   427→
   428→```typescript
   429→// SkillsSchema from src/lib/schemas.ts:
   430→SkillsSchema = z.object({
   431→  categories: z.array(z.object({
   432→    name: z.string(),
   433→    skills: z.array(z.string())  // <-- STRINGS ONLY!
   434→  }))
   435→});
   436→```
   437→
   438→**Before writing skills file**:
   439→1. Verify each skill is a plain string
   440→2. Move any evidence/level data to comments
   441→3. Test parse the YAML structure mentally

   463→## Schema Reference
   464→
   465→### Experience Entry
   466→```typescript
   467→{
   468→  company: string;      // Required
   469→  role: string;         // Required
   470→  period: string;       // Required: "YYYY – YYYY" or "YYYY – Present"
   471→  location: string;     // Required
   472→  logo?: string;        // Optional: path to logo
   473→  url?: string;         // Optional: company website - ALWAYS include if available
   474→  highlights: string[]; // Required: 3-4 items with [Product](url) links where possible
   475→  tags: string[];       // Required: 2-5 tags
   476→}
   477→```
   478→
   479→### Case Study Frontmatter
   480→```typescript
   481→{
   482→  id: number;           // Required: unique incremental
   483→  slug: string;         // Required: URL-friendly
   484→  title: string;        // Required
   485→  company: string;      // Required
   486→  year: string;         // Required: "YYYY" or "YYYY-YY"
   487→  tags: string[];       // Required
   488→  duration: string;     // Required
   489→  role: string;         // Required
   490→  hook: {
   491→    headline: string;
   492→    impactMetric: { value: string; label: string };
   493→    subMetrics?: { value: string; label: string }[];
   494→    thumbnail?: string;
   495→  };
   496→  cta: {
   497→    headline: string;
   498→    subtext?: string;
   499→    action: "contact" | "calendly" | "linkedin";
   500→    linkText: string;
   501→  };
   502→  // Optional links
   503→  demoUrl?: string;
   504→  githubUrl?: string;
   505→  docsUrl?: string;
   506→  media?: { type: string; url: string; label?: string }[];
   507→}
   508→```
   509→
   510→### Testimonial Entry
   511→```typescript
   512→{
   513→  quote: string;        // Required: the testimonial text
   514→  author: string;       // Required: name or title if anonymized
   515→  initials: string;     // Required: for avatar fallback
   516→  role: string;         // Required
   517→  company: string;      // Required
   518→  avatar?: string;      // Optional: image path
   519→  featured?: boolean;   // Optional: for prominent display
   520→}

   593→## Quality Criteria
   594→
   595→### "Hired-on-Sight" Standard
   596→
   597→Every piece of content should pass this test:
   598→
   599→- **Specific**: Numbers, names, technologies — not vague claims
   600→- **Verified**: Can point to source data
   601→- **Impactful**: Shows business/user value, not just activity
   602→- **Consistent**: Formatting, dates, terminology aligned
   603→- **Complete**: No "TODO" or placeholder content
   604→

    37→
    38→Liquidations, governance votes, whale movements—every major on-chain event was invisible until it was too late. Traders missed opportunities. Protocols couldn't react fast enough. Communities were always behind.
    39→
    40→## The Challenge
    41→
    42→Blockchains are transparent, but staying ahead of critical events required complex custom setups, constant polling, or expensive infrastructure. No simple way to get real-time notifications about what's happening on-chain.
    43→
    44→The constraints:
    45→- Bootstrapping solo with limited resources
    46→- Multiple chains needed (Ethereum, Cosmos ecosystem)
    47→- Sub-second latency or it's worthless—alerts after the fact are just news
    48→- Developer SDK simple enough for quick integration
    49→
    50→## The Approach
    51→
    52→The bet: a scenario-based alerting platform with no-code configuration. Make tracking whale wallets as easy as setting up a Google Alert.
    53→
    54→### Alternatives Considered
    55→
    56→| Option | Trade-offs | Why Not |
    57→|--------|------------|---------|
    58→| Build for enterprise only | Higher contract values, clearer monetization | Long sales cycles, needed traction fast |
    59→| Developer-only API | Simpler product, focused use case | Missed larger opportunity in no-code market |
    60→| Single chain focus | Faster development, deeper integration | Multi-chain was the clear direction of the ecosystem |
    61→
    62→We built both: no-code consumer platform AND developer SDK. Started with Cosmos where competition was thinner.
    63→
    64→## Key Decision
    65→
    66→**Launching as default alerting provider on Archway mainnet**
    67→
    68→Archway (Cosmos SDK L1) was launching their mainnet. I pitched Mempools as their official alerting infrastructure.
    69→
    70→Launched Archway-Alerts.com the same day as their mainnet. Became the default platform for the ecosystem.
    71→
    72→> Instead of competing for developers, we became the recommended solution. One partnership gave us instant distribution and credibility.
    73→
    74→## Execution
    75→
    76→### Phase 1: Core Platform (8 weeks)
    77→- Real-time event monitoring infrastructure on Ethereum
    78→- Scenario builder with AND/OR logic for complex alerts
    79→- Multi-channel delivery: Telegram, Discord, webhooks, email
    80→
    81→### Phase 2: SDK Development (4 weeks)
    82→- Published mempools-sdk to NPM
    83→- Documentation and quickstart guides
    84→- Embeddable UI templates for white-label deployments
    85→
    86→### Phase 3: Cosmos Expansion (4 weeks)
    87→- Extended to Archway, Juno, and Canto networks
    88→- Chain-specific event parsing for Cosmos transaction types
    89→- Archway-Alerts.com as flagship deployment
    90→
    91→### Phase 4: Partnerships (Ongoing)
    92→- Luganodes partnership for enhanced node infrastructure
    93→- Ecosystem projects onboarded as early adopters
    94→- Community building through Twitter Spaces and Discord
    95→
    96→## Results
    97→
    98→- **200+ Daily Active Users** — Organic growth through ecosystem partnerships
    99→- **Sub-second delivery** — Alerts arriving before users could manually check
   100→- **5 chains supported** — Ethereum, Arbitrum, Archway, Juno, Canto
   101→- **Default Archway provider** — Launched alongside mainnet as official platform
   102→
   103→The platform enabled use cases that weren't possible before: arbitrage bots reacting to on-chain signals, portfolio trackers with instant notifications, governance watchers alerting communities to votes.
   104→
   105→## What I Learned
   106→
   107→**What worked:**
   108→- Ecosystem partnerships over raw marketing—one protocol deal worth 100 Twitter impressions
   109→- No-code interface expanded addressable market beyond developers
   110→- Multi-channel delivery (Telegram/Discord) was table stakes for Web3
   111→- Launching with a chain's mainnet = instant distribution
   112→
   113→**What didn't:**
   114→- Underestimated infrastructure costs for real-time monitoring at scale
   115→- Built too many features initially—should have shipped MVP faster
   116→- Discord community building was slower ROI than direct partnership outreach
   117→- Cross-chain complexity higher than anticipated (each chain has different event formats)
   118→
   119→> First-time founder lesson: distribution beats product. Having Archway recommend us to their ecosystem was more valuable than any feature we could have built.
   120→
   121→If I did it again: even more aggressive on ecosystem partnerships from day 1. In crypto infrastructure, you win through distribution, not features.
   122→

## Goal
Create realistic mock career data in `source-data/` that tests the full cv-data-ingestion pipeline and enables realistic first-time-user skill simulations.

## Fictional Persona: "Alex Chen"
- **Role**: Full-stack engineer transitioning to Product Management
- **Experience**: 6 years across startups and mid-size companies
- **Domain**: FinTech, Developer Tools, AI/ML products
- **Location**: San Francisco, CA

This persona is different enough from the real portfolio owner (Dmitrii) to clearly be test data, while being realistic enough to test the entire pipeline.

---

## Files to Create

### 1. `source-data/mock-resume.md` - Primary Career Source
A markdown resume with:

- Education

CSV with columns:
- Company, Title, Start Date, End Date, Description
- Tests CSV parsing in cv-data-ingestion

### 3. `source-data/obsidian-vault/` - Rich Project Notes
Folder structure:
\```
obsidian-vault/
├── projects/
│   ├── api-platform-redesign.md
│   └── ml-ops-dashboard.md
├── work-journal/

### 4. `source-data/testimonials.txt` - Social Proof

### 5. `source-data/gemini-review.md` - AI Summary (High Priority)

### 6. `source-data/target-jd.txt` - Job Description for Variant Generation

| Format | File | Tests |
|--------|------|-------|

---
title: API Platform Redesign
project: DataFlow Core Platform
status: shipped
date: 2023-06-15
tags: [api, developer-experience, performance]
---

# API Platform Redesign

## Context

Our core API platform was showing its age. Built 4 years ago for 1K developers, we were now serving 15K+ with growing latency issues and developer complaints about onboarding friction.

## Problem Statement

1. **Performance**: P99 latency at 800ms, target was 300ms
2. **Onboarding**: Average time-to-first-API-call was 2+ hours
3. **Documentation**: Scattered across 3 different systems
4. **Rate limiting**: Blunt instrument causing false positives for legitimate users

## Approach

### Phase 1: Performance Foundation (Q1 2023)
- Migrated to edge-cached gateway
- Implemented connection pooling
- Added regional endpoints (US-East, US-West, EU-West)

### Phase 2: Developer Experience (Q2 2023)
- Unified documentation portal
- Interactive API explorer with live examples
- Self-service API key provisioning

### Phase 3: Smart Rate Limiting (Q3 2023)
- Usage-based quotas instead of hard limits
- Burst allowances for legitimate traffic spikes
- Real-time usage dashboards

## Results

| Metric | Before | After | Change |
|--------|--------|-------|--------|
| P99 Latency | 800ms | 280ms | -65% |
| Time to First Call | 2+ hours | 15 min | -87% |
| Developer NPS | 32 | 61 | +29 pts |
| Support Tickets | 150/week | 45/week | -70% |

## Key Decisions

### Edge caching vs Origin optimization
Chose edge caching because:
- Most requests were read-heavy (85% GETs)
- Geographic distribution of developers made edge beneficial
- Lower implementation risk than rewriting origin services

### Unified docs vs Embedded docs
Chose unified portal because:
- Single search across all resources
- Consistent versioning
- Easier to maintain

## Learnings

What worked:
- Early beta with power users shaped feature priorities
- Weekly office hours with developers surfaced unexpected pain points
- Metrics dashboard built early helped tell the story internally

What I'd do differently:
- Start with mobile SDK users earlier (they had unique needs)
- Build migration tooling before announcing deprecation timeline
- More aggressive communication about new features

## Team

- 5 backend engineers
- 2 frontend engineers
- 1 designer
- 1 data scientist (for usage analytics)

## Links

- [API Docs](https://docs.dataflow.example.com)
- [Migration Guide](https://docs.dataflow.example.com/migration)
- [Case Study Blog Post](https://blog.dataflow.example.com/api-redesign)

# ML-Ops Dashboard Project

Quick notes from the ML code completion feature launch.

## Background

We wanted to add AI-powered code completion to our developer tools. This was a big bet - $500K+ in ML infrastructure costs, but potential to 10x developer productivity.

## What we shipped

- Real-time code suggestions powered by fine-tuned LLM
- Context-aware completions that understood our API semantics
- Latency target: <100ms for suggestions
- Privacy-first: no code stored, on-device inference option

## Metrics after 3 months

- 8K developers using it actively
- 92% satisfaction score
- 40% reduction in boilerplate code written
- 15% faster API integration time

## Technical architecture

Pretty standard ML ops setup:
- Model serving on dedicated GPU cluster
- A/B testing framework for model variants
- Feedback loop for continuous improvement
- Fallback to simpler heuristics when ML unavailable

## Challenges

1. **Latency**: Initial model was too slow (300ms). Had to distill to smaller model.
2. **Context windows**: Needed smart truncation for large codebases
3. **Multi-language**: Supporting Python, JavaScript, Go, Java required separate training

## Team dynamics

Cross-functional was key:
- ML engineers owned model
- Platform engineers owned serving infrastructure
- I owned product requirements and success metrics
- Designer created the inline suggestion UI

The hardest part was aligning ML team's "ship when perfect" culture with product's "iterate fast" approach. We compromised: MVP with clear quality bar, then rapid iteration.

## What's next

- Expand to more languages (Rust, TypeScript)
- Add "explain this code" feature
- Explore fine-tuning on customer-specific codebases (enterprise tier)

## Approved Plan:
# Mock Data for First-Time User Skill

## Goal
Create realistic mock career data in `source-data/` that tests the full cv-data-ingestion pipeline and enables realistic first-time-user skill simulations.

## Fictional Persona: "Alex Chen"
- **Role**: Full-stack engineer transitioning to Product Management
- **Experience**: 6 years across startups and mid-size companies
- **Domain**: FinTech, Developer Tools, AI/ML products
- **Location**: San Francisco, CA

This persona is different enough from the real portfolio owner (Dmitrii) to clearly be test data, while being realistic enough to test the entire pipeline.

---

## Files to Create

### 1. `source-data/mock-resume.md` - Primary Career Source
A markdown resume with:
- 3 roles (Product Manager, Senior Engineer, Engineer)
- Achievements with specific metrics
- Skills section
- Education

### 2. `source-data/linkedin-export.csv` - Structured Data
CSV with columns:
- Company, Title, Start Date, End Date, Description
- Tests CSV parsing in cv-data-ingestion

### 3. `source-data/project-notes/` - Rich Project Documentation
Various formats that users might have:
```
project-notes/
├── api-platform-redesign.md      # Markdown (Notion export style)
├── ml-ops-dashboard.md           # Plain markdown
├── quarterly-review.txt          # Plain text notes
└── performance-review-2023.md    # HR document style
```
Tests parsing of various markdown/text formats without requiring specific tools like Obsidian.

### 4. `source-data/testimonials.txt` - Social Proof
2-3 LinkedIn-style recommendations with:
- Quote text
- Author name, role, company
- Tests testimonial extraction

### 5. `source-data/gemini-review.md` - AI Summary (High Priority)
Pre-processed summary that cv-data-ingestion should detect and use first. Includes:
- Structured career summary
- Key achievements
- Skills taxonomy
Tests priority processing of AI summaries.

### 6. `source-data/target-jd.txt` - Job Description for Variant Generation
A realistic Product Manager job posting to test:
- analyze:jd command
- search:evidence command
- generate:cv variant targeting

### 7. `source-data/documents/` - PDFs and Formal Documents
```
documents/
├── alex-chen-resume.pdf         # PDF resume (exported from markdown)
├── certificate-aws-solutions.pdf # Mock certification
└── performance-summary-2023.pdf  # Annual review document
```
Tests PDF parsing capabilities.

### 8. `source-data/images/` - Visual Artifacts
```
images/
├── architecture-diagram.png      # System design diagram
├── product-roadmap.png           # Roadmap screenshot
├── dashboard-metrics.png         # Analytics dashboard
└── team-photo.jpg               # Professional photo
```
Tests image cataloging for case study thumbnails and profile photos.

---

## Data Diversity Checklist

| Format | File | Tests |
|--------|------|-------|
| Markdown resume | mock-resume.md | Text parsing, section detection |
| CSV | linkedin-export.csv | Structured data parsing |
| Project notes | project-notes/ | Folder scanning, various markdown formats |
| Plain text | testimonials.txt | Testimonial extraction heuristics |
| AI summary | gemini-review.md | Priority detection, structured format |
| Job description | target-jd.txt | JD analysis, variant generation |
| PDF documents | documents/ | PDF parsing, resume extraction |
| Images/diagrams | images/ | Visual cataloging, thumbnails |

---

1. Create `source-data/mock-resume.md` with Alex Chen's career
2. Create `source-data/linkedin-export.csv` with position history
3. Create `source-data/project-notes/` folder with markdown and text files

7. Create `source-data/documents/` with PDF resume and certificates
8. Create `source-data/images/` with diagrams and visual artifacts

**Note on PDFs/Images**: Will generate simple placeholder files or use minimal valid file formats. The key is having the file structure for testing - the ingestion skill will attempt to parse/catalog them.

- **Realistic metrics**: "40% reduction", "15K DAU", "$2M ARR" (not impossible numbers)
- **Consistent timeline**: 2018-2024 career progression
- **Cross-references**: Same projects mentioned across multiple files (tests deduplication)
- **Variety of formats**: Bullet points, paragraphs, YAML frontmatter, CSV rows
- **Intentional gaps**: Some missing data to test gap analysis reporting

   196→## 6. Host on GitHub Pages

   200→### Step 1: Create GitHub Repository
   201→
   202→```bash

   214→
   215→### Step 2: Add GitHub Actions Workflow
   216→
   217→Create `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`:
   218→
   219→```yaml
   220→name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
   221→
   222→on:
   223→  push:
   224→    branches: [main]
   225→
   226→permissions:
   227→  contents: read
   228→  pages: write
   229→  id-token: write
   230→
   231→jobs:
   232→  build:
   233→    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   234→    steps:
   235→      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
   236→
   237→      - name: Setup Node
   238→        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
   239→        with:
   240→          node-version: 20
   241→          cache: npm
   242→
   243→      - name: Install dependencies
   244→        run: npm ci
   245→
   246→      - name: Build
   247→        run: npm run build
   248→
   249→      - name: Upload artifact
   250→        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
   251→        with:
   252→          path: dist
   253→
   254→  deploy:
   255→    needs: build
   256→    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   257→    environment:
   258→      name: github-pages
   259→      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
   260→    steps:
   261→      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
   262→        id: deployment
   263→        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
   264→```
   265→
   266→### Step 3: Enable GitHub Pages
   267→
   268→1. Go to repository Settings → Pages
   269→2. Source: "GitHub Actions"

   390→## 8.5 Prerequisites: API Key Setup
   391→
   392→**Outcome:** Environment configured for AI-powered variant generation
   393→
   394→Before generating variants with AI, you need an API key from one of these providers:
   395→
   396→### Option A: Anthropic Claude (Recommended)

   398→1. Create an account at https://console.anthropic.com

   404→### Option B: OpenAI
   405→
   406→1. Create an account at https://platform.openai.com
   407→2. Navigate to API Keys and create a new key

   409→
   410→**Pricing:** ~$0.01-0.05 per variant generation. See https://openai.com/pricing

   412→### Option C: Google Gemini
   413→

   434→## 9. Generate Job Variants
   435→
   436→**Outcome:** Personalized portfolio tailored to specific job applications
   437→
   438→This is the power feature - create targeted versions of your portfolio for each job you apply to.
   439→
   440→### Recipe
   441→
   442→**Skill:** `/generate-variant`
   443→
   444→```
   445→Input:  Job description text
   446→        content/knowledge/achievements/*.yaml
   447→Output: content/variants/company-role.yaml
   448→        content/variants/company-role.json
   449→        capstone/develop/evals/company-role.claims.yaml
   450→        capstone/develop/redteam/company-role.redteam.md
   451→```
   452→
   453→### How to Use
   454→
   455→1. Copy the job description
   456→2. Start a Claude Code session
   457→3. Say: "Generate a variant for this job using /generate-variant"
   458→4. Paste the job description
   459→
   460→### The 7-Phase Pipeline
   461→
   462→The skill runs automatically through:
   463→
   464→1. **Job Analysis** - Extracts requirements from JD
   465→2. **Knowledge Query** - Finds matching achievements in your knowledge base
   466→3. **Content Generation** - Tailors hero, about, and stats
   467→4. **File Creation** - Creates YAML + syncs to JSON
   468→5. **Evaluation** - Verifies all claims against knowledge base
   469→6. **Red Team** - Scans for accuracy, tone, and security issues
   470→7. **Review** - Visual check before publishing
   471→
   472→### View Your Variant
   473→
   474→```bash
   475→# Start dev server
   476→npm run dev
   477→
   478→# Open variant URL
   479→open "http://localhost:5173/#/company/role"
   480→```
   481→
   482→### Quality Gates
   483→
   484→```bash
   485→# Verify all claims
   486→npm run eval:check
   487→
   488→# Run security scan
   489→npm run redteam:check
   490→```

# First-Time User Experience Audit

**Date:** 2025-12-27
**Persona:** Alex Chen, Senior Product Manager
**Goal:** Test the cv-data-ingestion and generate-variant workflows using mock data
**Mock Data Location:** `source-data/` (18 files created for testing)

---

## Executive Summary

- **Overall Score:** 9/10
- **Time to First Success:** ~5 minutes for CLI tools, blocked on variant generation (API quota)
- **Critical Blockers:** 0
- **Friction Points:** 2 (minor)
- **CLI Score:** 10/10 (automated audit passed all 13 tests)

---

## Journey Map

| Step | Status | Friction Level | Notes |
|------|--------|----------------|-------|
| Find entry point (GETTING_STARTED_GUIDE.md) | Success | Low | Clear file naming, but multiple guides exist |
| Verify source-data/ structure | Success | None | Data matched expected format |
| Check .env.example | Success | None | File exists with clear instructions |
| List npm scripts | Success | None | Clear script names |
| Test generate:cv --help | Success | None | Excellent help with examples |
| Test analyze:jd | Success | None | Clear colored output |
| Run npm run audit:cli | Success | None | 10/10 score, all tests pass |
| Run npm run validate | Success | None | 26 files validated |
| Generate variant (API) | Partial | Medium | API quota exceeded |

---

## Critical Blockers

**None found.** All core workflows are accessible and documented.

---

## Friction Points

### 1. Section Numbering in GETTING_STARTED_GUIDE.md (Low)

**Issue:** Section 8.5 (API Keys) comes between Section 8 (Blog Posts) and Section 9 (Variants). This is confusing - API key setup should come earlier or have a different number.

**Recommendation:** Renumber sections or move API key setup to Section 1.5 (after Quick Start).

**Priority:** Low

---

### 2. .env.local Not Auto-Loaded by CLI (Medium)

**Issue:** The `generate:cv` script doesn't automatically load `.env.local`. Users must either:
- Export the variable manually: `export GEMINI_API_KEY=...`
- Pass via flag: `--api-key "..."`
- Prefix the command: `GEMINI_API_KEY=... npm run generate:cv ...`

**Current behavior:**
\```bash
# This fails:
npm run generate:cv -- --company X --role Y --jd file.txt --provider gemini
# Error: No API key found

# These work:
GEMINI_API_KEY=... npm run generate:cv -- ...
npm run generate:cv -- --api-key "..." --company X ...
\```

**Recommendation:** Use `dotenv` to auto-load `.env.local` in CLI scripts, or document the workaround clearly in --help.

**Priority:** Medium

---

## CLI Tool Assessment

| Tool | Help | Errors | Output | JSON | Rating |
|------|------|--------|--------|------|--------|
| validate | N/A | N/A | Clear | No | 10/10 |

| ucv-cli | Good | Helpful | Clear | Yes | 10/10 |
| variants:sync | N/A | N/A | Clear | N/A | 10/10 |

**Overall CLI Score:** 10/10 (automated audit confirmed)

---

## Recommendations

### Priority 1 (Critical)
*None - system is production-ready*

### Priority 2 (High)
1. **Auto-load .env.local in CLI scripts** - Add `dotenv` loading to `generate-cv.ts` and other scripts that need API keys

### Priority 3 (Medium)
1. **Renumber GETTING_STARTED_GUIDE sections** - Move API key setup earlier (Section 1.5 or 2)
2. **Add retry logic for API rate limits** - Suggest waiting or offer to retry after delay

---

## What Worked Well

1. **GETTING_STARTED_GUIDE.md** - Clear recipe format with outcomes, inputs, and outputs
2. **CLI help messages** - Excellent help with `--help` flag, including examples and links
3. **Error messages** - Helpful errors with specific fix instructions
4. **Automated CLI audit** - Self-testing capability (`npm run audit:cli`) is excellent
5. **Mock data support** - `source-data/` structure matches documentation exactly
6. **Validation** - `npm run validate` provides clear pass/fail feedback
7. **JSON output** - All analysis tools support `--json` for scripting

---

## Conclusion

The Universal CV system provides an excellent first-time user experience. Documentation is clear, CLI tools are well-designed with helpful error messages, and the automated audit capability provides confidence in system reliability.

The main gap is that variant generation requires external API access, which introduces dependencies on third-party rate limits. The documentation already covers manual variant creation as a fallback, which is appropriate.

**Verdict:** Production-ready with minor improvements suggested.

   250→export const BlogPostSchema = z.object({
   251→  title: z.string(),
   252→  date: z.string().regex(/^\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2}$/, 'Date must be in YYYY-MM-DD format'),
   253→  excerpt: z.string(),
   254→  tags: z.array(z.string()),
   255→  thumbnail: z.string().nullable().optional(),
   256→  content: z.string()
   257→});
   258→
   259→// ------------------------------------------------------------------
   260→// VARIANT CV (Universal Portfolio)
   261→// ------------------------------------------------------------------
   262→
   263→/**
   264→ * Metadata about the variant generation
   265→ */
   266→const VariantMetadataSchema = z.object({
   267→  company: z.string(),
   268→  role: z.string(),
   269→  generatedAt: z.string(),
   270→  jobDescription: z.string(),
   271→  generationModel: z.string().optional(), // e.g., "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022"
   272→  slug: z.string(), // e.g., "bloomberg-senior-engineer"
   273→  publishStatus: z.enum(['draft', 'published']).optional().default('draft'),
   274→  publishedAt: z.string().optional(),
   275→  applicationStatus: z.enum(['not_applied', 'applied']).optional().default('not_applied'),
   276→  appliedAt: z.string().optional()
   277→});
   278→
   279→/**
   280→ * Experience override - allows tailoring job highlights per variant
   281→ */
   282→const ExperienceOverrideSchema = z.object({
   283→  company: z.string(), // Match by company name
   284→  highlights: z.array(z.string()).optional(), // Override highlights for this company
   285→  tags: z.array(z.string()).optional() // Override tags for this company
   286→});
   287→
   288→/**
   289→ * Overrides for profile fields specific to this variant
   290→ * All fields optional - only override what's relevant for the job
   291→ */
   292→const VariantOverridesSchema = z.object({
   293→  hero: z.object({
   294→    status: z.string().optional(),
   295→    headline: z.array(HeadlineSegmentSchema).optional(),
   296→    subheadline: z.string().optional(),
   297→    // Company accent - shown below signature headline to help recruiters visualize fit
   298→    companyAccent: z.array(HeadlineSegmentSchema).optional()
   299→  }).optional(),
   300→  about: z.object({
   301→    tagline: z.string().optional(),
   302→    bio: z.array(z.string()).optional(),
   303→    stats: z.array(StatSchema).optional()
   304→  }).optional(),
   305→  sections: z.object({
   306→    beyondWork: z.boolean().optional(),
   307→    blog: z.boolean().optional(),
   308→    onchainIdentity: z.boolean().optional(),
   309→    skills: z.boolean().optional(),
   310→    passionProjects: z.boolean().optional()
   311→  }).optional(),
   312→  // Experience customization - tailor highlights per company for this job
   313→  experience: z.array(ExperienceOverrideSchema).optional()
   314→});
   315→
   316→/**
   317→ * Relevance rankings for existing content
   318→ * AI determines which case studies, projects, skills to emphasize
   319→ */
   320→const VariantRelevanceSchema = z.object({
   321→  caseStudies: z.array(z.object({
   322→    slug: z.string(),
   323→    relevanceScore: z.number().min(0).max(1),
   324→    reasoning: z.string().optional()
   325→  })).optional(),
   326→  skills: z.array(z.object({
   327→    category: z.string(),
   328→    relevanceScore: z.number().min(0).max(1)
   329→  })).optional(),
   330→  projects: z.array(z.object({
   331→    slug: z.string(),
   332→    relevanceScore: z.number().min(0).max(1),
   333→    reasoning: z.string().optional()
   334→  })).optional()
   335→});
   336→
   337→/**
   338→ * Complete variant schema - combines metadata, overrides, and relevance
   339→ */
   340→export const VariantSchema = z.object({
   341→  metadata: VariantMetadataSchema,
   342→  overrides: VariantOverridesSchema,
   343→  relevance: VariantRelevanceSchema.optional()
   344→});

---
id: 1
slug: api-platform-redesign
title: "API Platform Redesign"
company: "DataFlow Labs"
year: "2023"
tags: [API Platform, Developer Experience, Performance, B2B SaaS]
duration: "6 months"
role: "Senior Product Manager"

hook:
  headline: "Led API platform redesign reducing latency 65% while growing revenue 158%"
  impactMetric:
    value: "65%"
    label: "latency reduction"
  subMetrics:
    - value: "15K+"
      label: "daily active developers"
    - value: "$3.1M"
      label: "ARR achieved"
  thumbnail: null

cta:
  headline: "Building developer infrastructure?"
  subtext: "I've shipped platforms that developers actually love to use."
  action: calendly
  linkText: "Let's talk →"
---

Our core API platform was showing its age. Built 4 years ago for 1K developers, we were now serving 15K+ with growing latency issues and developer complaints about onboarding friction.

## The Challenge

The platform faced four critical problems:
1. **Performance**: P99 latency at 800ms, target was 300ms
2. **Onboarding**: Average time-to-first-API-call was 2+ hours
3. **Documentation**: Scattered across 3 different systems
4. **Rate limiting**: Blunt instrument causing false positives for legitimate users

## The Approach

### Phase 1: Performance Foundation
- Migrated to edge-cached gateway
- Implemented connection pooling
- Added regional endpoints (US-East, US-West, EU-West)

### Phase 2: Developer Experience
- Unified documentation portal
- Interactive API explorer with live examples
- Self-service API key provisioning

### Phase 3: Smart Rate Limiting
- Usage-based quotas instead of hard limits
- Burst allowances for legitimate traffic spikes
- Real-time usage dashboards

## Key Decision

**Edge caching vs Origin optimization**

Chose edge caching because:
- Most requests were read-heavy (85% GETs)
- Geographic distribution of developers made edge beneficial
- Lower implementation risk than rewriting origin services

## Results

| Metric | Before | After | Change |
|--------|--------|-------|--------|
| P99 Latency | 800ms | 280ms | -65% |
| Time to First Call | 2+ hours | 15 min | -87% |
| Developer NPS | 32 | 61 | +29 pts |
| Support Tickets | 150/week | 45/week | -70% |

## What I Learned

**What worked:**
- Early beta with power users shaped feature priorities
- Weekly office hours with developers surfaced unexpected pain points
- Metrics dashboard built early helped tell the story internally

**What I'd do differently:**
- Start with mobile SDK users earlier (they had unique needs)
- Build migration tooling before announcing deprecation timeline
- More aggressive communication about new features

> Developer experience is a product. Treat it like one.

```

   150→
   151→## Part V: Capstone Quality Pipeline
   152→
   153→### Overview
   154→
   155→YAML is canonical. JSON is derived. Every claim must be traceable.
   156→
   157→```
   158→JD Analysis → Alignment Gate → Knowledge Base → Variant YAML → sync → JSON → eval → redteam → Deploy
   159→```
   160→
   161→### Pre-Generation Scripts (Deterministic)
   162→
   163→These scripts run BEFORE generating variants, reducing AI judgment overhead:
   164→
   165→```bash
   166→# ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
   167→# JD ANALYSIS — Extract requirements, filter generic phrases
   168→# ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
   169→npm run analyze:jd -- --file source-data/jd-{company}.txt --save
   170→# Output: capstone/develop/jd-analysis/{slug}.yaml
   171→
   172→# ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
   173→# EVIDENCE SEARCH — Search knowledge base for alignment
   174→# ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
   175→npm run search:evidence -- --jd-analysis capstone/develop/jd-analysis/{slug}.yaml --save
   176→npm run search:evidence -- --terms "crypto,staking,api" --threshold 0.5
   177→# Output: capstone/develop/alignment/{slug}.yaml
   178→
   179→# ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
   180→# COVERAGE CHECK — Categorize bullets into 7 PM competency bundles
   181→# ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
   182→npm run check:coverage
   183→npm run check:coverage -- --json
   184→```
   185→
   186→**What they do:**
   187→| Script | Purpose | Output |
   188→|--------|---------|--------|
   189→| `analyze:jd` | Filters 47+ generic phrases, extracts must-haves | JD analysis YAML |
   190→| `search:evidence` | Searches achievements/stories, scores alignment | Alignment report |
   191→| `check:coverage` | Categorizes bullets into 7 PM competency bundles | Coverage matrix |
   192→
   193→**The 7 PM Competency Bundles:**
   194→1. Product Design & Development
   195→2. Leadership & Execution
   196→3. Strategy & Planning
   197→4. Business & Marketing
   198→5. Project Management
   199→6. Technical & Analytical
   200→7. Communication
   201→
   202→### Post-Generation Commands
   203→
   204→```bash
   205→npm run variants:sync              # YAML→JSON
   206→npm run eval:variant -- --slug X   # Generate claims ledger
   207→npm run redteam:variant -- --slug X # Adversarial scan
   208→npm run ucv-cli                    # Interactive dashboard
   209→```
   210→
   211→### Quality Gates
   212→
   213→| Check | Catches |
   214→|-------|---------|
   215→| `RT-SEC-SECRETS` | API keys, tokens |
   216→| `RT-SEC-CONFIDENTIAL` | NDA language |
   217→| `RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY` | "thrilled", "dream company" |
   218→| `RT-XVAR-CONTAM` | Mentions other target company |
   219→
   220→### Files Reference
   221→
   222→| Purpose | Path |
   223→|---------|------|
   224→| JD Analysis | `capstone/develop/jd-analysis/*.yaml` |
   225→| Alignment Reports | `capstone/develop/alignment/*.yaml` |
   226→| Workflow Guide | `docs/guides/capstone-workflow.md` |

### 5. Performance Concerns

**Critical Issues:**
1. **No responsive variants** - Same image served to mobile (375px) and desktop (1920px)
2. **Large PNG case studies** - 269-422KB each uncompressed
3. **No format negotiation** - Missing WebP/AVIF for modern browsers
4. **No dynamic sizing** - Images don't adapt to viewport
5. **Placeholder fallbacks** - Using external placeholder service instead of local
6. **No caching strategy** - No Cache-Control headers visible
7. **Author avatar duplication** - Same image loaded multiple times with different sizes
8. **No blur-up placeholder** - Blog images have CSS blur but not lightweight placeholder

**Secondary Issues:**
1. Markdown images from blog posts have no optimization (via ReactMarkdown)
2. No image preloading for critical images (hero, OG images)
3. No loading states except CSS blur effect
4. Error handling uses external URL instead of inline SVG/CSS

### Recommended Optimized Image Component

An optimized Image component should provide:

```typescript
interface OptimizedImageProps {
  // Basic
  src: string;
  alt: string;
  
  // Responsiveness
  width?: number | string;
  height?: number | string;
  aspectRatio?: 'square' | '3/4' | '4/3' | '16/9' | string;
  
  // Sizes for responsive loading
  sizes?: string; // e.g., "(max-width: 768px) 100vw, 50vw"
  srcSet?: Record<number, string>; // e.g., { 400: 'img-400.webp', 800: 'img-800.webp' }
  
  // Optimization
  format?: 'webp' | 'avif' | 'jpeg' | 'png' | 'auto'; // auto = detect + fallback
  quality?: number; // 0-100, default 80
  
  // Loading behavior
  loading?: 'lazy' | 'eager' | 'auto';
  decoding?: 'async' | 'sync' | 'auto';
  placeholder?: 'blur' | 'empty' | 'dataurl'; // LQIP strategies
  
  // Fallback & error handling
  fallback?: React.ReactNode; // component or string
  onError?: () => void;
  
  // Styling
  fill?: boolean; // absolute fill container
  cover?: boolean; // object-fit: cover
  contain?: boolean; // object-fit: contain
  className?: string;
  style?: React.CSSProperties;
  
  // Metadata
  priority?: boolean; // adds preload + fetchPriority
  title?: string;
}
```

**Features to Implement:**

1. **Format Negotiation**
   - Serve WebP to modern browsers, JPEG/PNG fallback
   - AVIF as premium format for latest browsers
   - Automatic format detection via Accept header or UA parsing

2. **Responsive Images**
   - Generate srcSet variants at build time (400px, 800px, 1200px, 1600px)
   - Mobile-first sizing: `(max-width: 640px) 100vw, (max-width: 1024px) 50vw, 33vw`
   - Separate breakpoints for different image types (hero vs thumbnail)

3. **Lazy Loading**
   - Intersection Observer for true lazy loading
   - Native `loading="lazy"` fallback
   - Threshold-based loading (load before entering viewport)

4. **Placeholder Strategies**
   - Blur-up: Ultra-low quality version (10-30KB) shown during load
   - Data URL: Inline base64 mini-image
   - CSS skeleton: Simple background gradient
   - Empty: Nothing until load

5. **Image Optimization at Build**
   - Sharp plugin for Vite to auto-generate variants
   - AVIF, WebP, JPEG/PNG formats
   - Metadata extraction (dimensions, aspect ratio)
   - Automatic srcSet generation

6. **Performance Features**
   - Priority images get `<link rel="preload">` + `fetchPriority="high"`
   - Preconnect to CDN if used
   - Cache busting with content hash
   - Error boundary with graceful fallback

7. **Analytics Integration**
   - Track loading performance (LCP, image load time)
   - Log failed image loads
   - Monitor format usage (WebP adoption rate)

8. **Use Cases in Portfolio**
   - **Profile photo**: priority, blur-up, cover
   - **Case study thumbnails**: lazy, responsive, aspect 4/3 or auto
   - **Blog hero**: priority, blur-up, 16/9 aspect, fullwidth
   - **Company logos**: lazy, contain, no optimization (already SVG)
   - **OG images**: preload + fetchPriority for social sharing

---

### Implementation Strategy

**Phase 1: Create Base Component**
- `/src/components/common/Image.tsx` - Core component
- Implement format negotiation and srcSet generation
- Add error boundary and fallback UI

**Phase 2: Build Integration**
- Create Vite plugin or use existing sharp plugin
- Generate image variants during build
- Output metadata JSON for component consumption

**Phase 3: Migration**
- Convert critical images first (profile, hero, OG)
- Update AboutSection, BlogPostPage, CaseStudiesSection
- Add priority props to above-fold images

**Phase 4: Markdown Images**
- Create custom ReactMarkdown image component
- Auto-apply optimization to all inline blog images
- Generate variants for markdown image srcSet

**Phase 5: Monitoring**
- Add performance metrics tracking
- Monitor Core Web Vitals (LCP, CLS, FID)
- Track image load failures and format adoption

---

### Summary

**Current State:** Basic, unoptimized image handling with minimal lazy loading and no responsive variants.

**Key Gaps:** No format negotiation, no build-time optimization, no adaptive image serving, inconsistent error handling.

**Impact:** Potentially 50-70% larger downloads on mobile, slower LCP scores, missed performance optimization opportunities.

**Priority:** High - Images represent significant portion of bundle size, and optimization has direct SEO/UX impact.

     6→
     7→// Parse {{accent}}...{{/accent}} markers in text
     8→function parseStyledText(text: string): ReactNode[] {
     9→  const parts: ReactNode[] = [];
    10→  let lastIndex = 0;
    11→
    12→  // Use matchAll to avoid global regex state issues
    13→  for (const match of text.matchAll(/\{\{accent\}\}(.*?)\{\{\/accent\}\}/g)) {
    14→    // Add text before the match
    15→    if (match.index! > lastIndex) {
    16→      parts.push(text.slice(lastIndex, match.index));
    17→    }
    18→    // Add styled text
    19→    parts.push(
    20→      <span key={match.index} style={{
    21→        color: 'var(--color-accent)',
    22→        fontFamily: 'var(--font-serif)',
    23→        fontStyle: 'italic',
    24→        fontWeight: 600,
    25→        fontSize: '1.2em'
    26→      }}>
    27→        {match[1]}
    28→      </span>
    29→    );
    30→    lastIndex = match.index! + match[0].length;
    31→  }
    32→
    33→  // Add remaining text
    34→  if (lastIndex < text.length) {
    35→    parts.push(text.slice(lastIndex));
    36→  }
    37→
    38→  return parts.length > 0 ? parts : [text];
    39→}

     1→/**
     2→ * Blog Post Likes System
     3→ *
     4→ * Manages like functionality with client-side persistence and tracking.
     5→ * Stores like data in localStorage with user tracking information.
     6→ */
     7→
     8→export interface LikeData {
     9→    postSlug: string;
    10→    count: number;
    11→    timestamp: number;
    12→    userFingerprint: string;
    13→}
    14→
    15→export interface UserLike {
    16→    postSlug: string;
    17→    timestamp: number;
    18→    userAgent: string;
    19→    fingerprintHash: string;
    20→}
    21→
    22→const LIKES_STORAGE_KEY = 'blog-post-likes';
    23→const USER_LIKES_KEY = 'user-likes';
    24→const USER_FINGERPRINT_KEY = 'user-fingerprint';
    25→
    26→/**
    27→ * Generate a simple fingerprint for the user
    28→ * Uses browser characteristics to create a semi-stable identifier
    29→ */
    30→function generateUserFingerprint(): string {
    31→    const canvas = document.createElement('canvas');
    32→    const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');
    33→    if (ctx) {
    34→        ctx.textBaseline = 'top';
    35→        ctx.font = '14px Arial';
    36→        ctx.fillText('fingerprint', 2, 2);
    37→    }
    38→
    39→    const components = [
    40→        navigator.userAgent,
    41→        navigator.language,
    42→        screen.colorDepth,
    43→        screen.width + 'x' + screen.height,
    44→        new Date().getTimezoneOffset(),
    45→        canvas.toDataURL()
    46→    ];
    47→
    48→    // Simple DJB2 hash function
    49→    const str = components.join('|');
    50→    let hash = 0;
    51→    for (let i = 0; i < str.length; i++) {
    52→        const char = str.charCodeAt(i);
    53→        hash = ((hash << 5) - hash) + char;
    54→    }
    55→
    56→    return Math.abs(hash).toString(36);
    57→}
    58→
    59→/**
    60→ * Get or create user fingerprint
    61→ */
    62→function getUserFingerprint(): string {
    63→    try {
    64→        let fingerprint = localStorage.getItem(USER_FINGERPRINT_KEY);
    65→        if (!fingerprint) {
    66→            fingerprint = generateUserFingerprint();
    67→            localStorage.setItem(USER_FINGERPRINT_KEY, fingerprint);
    68→        }
    69→        return fingerprint;
    70→    } catch {
    71→        // Fallback if localStorage is not available
    72→        return generateUserFingerprint();
    73→    }
    74→}
    75→
    76→/**
    77→ * Get all likes from storage
    78→ */
    79→function getAllLikes(): Record<string, LikeData> {
    80→    try {
    81→        const data = localStorage.getItem(LIKES_STORAGE_KEY);
    82→        return data ? JSON.parse(data) : {};
    83→    } catch {
    84→        return {};
    85→    }
    86→}
    87→
    88→/**
    89→ * Save likes to storage
    90→ */
    91→function saveLikes(likes: Record<string, LikeData>): void {
    92→    try {
    93→        localStorage.setItem(LIKES_STORAGE_KEY, JSON.stringify(likes));
    94→    } catch (error) {
    95→        console.error('Failed to save likes:', error);
    96→    }
    97→}
    98→
    99→/**
   100→ * Get user's likes from storage
   101→ */
   102→function getUserLikes(): UserLike[] {
   103→    try {
   104→        const data = localStorage.getItem(USER_LIKES_KEY);
   105→        return data ? JSON.parse(data) : [];
   106→    } catch {
   107→        return [];
   108→    }
   109→}
   110→
   111→/**
   112→ * Save user's likes to storage
   113→ */
   114→function saveUserLikes(userLikes: UserLike[]): void {
   115→    try {
   116→        localStorage.setItem(USER_LIKES_KEY, JSON.stringify(userLikes));
   117→    } catch (error) {
   118→        console.error('Failed to save user likes:', error);
   119→    }
   120→}
   121→
   122→/**
   123→ * Check if user has liked a post
   124→ */
   125→export function hasUserLikedPost(postSlug: string): boolean {
   126→    const userLikes = getUserLikes();
   127→    return userLikes.some(like => like.postSlug === postSlug);
   128→}
   129→
   130→/**
   131→ * Get like count for a post
   132→ */
   133→export function getLikeCount(postSlug: string): number {
   134→    const likes = getAllLikes();
   135→    return likes[postSlug]?.count || 0;
   136→}
   137→
   138→/**
   139→ * Like a post (increment count)
   140→ */
   141→export function likePost(postSlug: string): { count: number; success: boolean } {
   142→    try {
   143→        // Check if already liked
   144→        if (hasUserLikedPost(postSlug)) {
   145→            return { count: getLikeCount(postSlug), success: false };
   146→        }
   147→
   148→        const likes = getAllLikes();
   149→        const fingerprint = getUserFingerprint();
   150→        const timestamp = Date.now();
   151→
   152→        // Update like count
   153→        if (!likes[postSlug]) {
   154→            likes[postSlug] = {
   155→                postSlug,
   156→                count: 0,
   157→                timestamp,
   158→                userFingerprint: fingerprint
   159→            };
   160→        }
   161→        likes[postSlug].count += 1;
   162→        saveLikes(likes);
   163→
   164→        // Track user's like
   165→        const userLikes = getUserLikes();
   166→        userLikes.push({
   167→            postSlug,
   168→            timestamp,
   169→            userAgent: navigator.userAgent,
   170→            fingerprintHash: fingerprint
   171→        });
   172→        saveUserLikes(userLikes);
   173→
   174→        return { count: likes[postSlug].count, success: true };
   175→    } catch (error) {
   176→        console.error('Failed to like post:', error);
   177→        return { count: getLikeCount(postSlug), success: false };
   178→    }
   179→}
   180→
   181→/**
   182→ * Unlike a post (decrement count)
   183→ */
   184→export function unlikePost(postSlug: string): { count: number; success: boolean } {
   185→    try {
   186→        // Check if user has liked this post
   187→        if (!hasUserLikedPost(postSlug)) {
   188→            return { count: getLikeCount(postSlug), success: false };
   189→        }
   190→
   191→        const likes = getAllLikes();
   192→
   193→        // Decrement count
   194→        if (likes[postSlug] && likes[postSlug].count > 0) {
   195→            likes[postSlug].count -= 1;
   196→            saveLikes(likes);
   197→        }
   198→
   199→        // Remove from user's likes
   200→        const userLikes = getUserLikes();
   201→        const updatedUserLikes = userLikes.filter(like => like.postSlug !== postSlug);
   202→        saveUserLikes(updatedUserLikes);
   203→
   204→        return { count: likes[postSlug]?.count || 0, success: true };
   205→    } catch (error) {
   206→        console.error('Failed to unlike post:', error);
   207→        return { count: getLikeCount(postSlug), success: false };
   208→    }
   209→}
   210→
   211→/**
   212→ * Get all posts with likes (for analytics)
   213→ */
   214→export function getAllPostLikes(): LikeData[] {
   215→    const likes = getAllLikes();
   216→    return Object.values(likes).sort((a, b) => b.count - a.count);
   217→}
   218→
   219→/**
   220→ * Get all user likes (for analytics)

   222→export function getAllUserLikes(): UserLike[] {
   223→    return getUserLikes().sort((a, b) => b.timestamp - a.timestamp);
   224→}
   225→
   226→/**
   227→ * Export likes data as JSON (for backup/analysis)
   228→ */
   229→export function exportLikesData(): string {
   230→    return JSON.stringify({

   232→        userLikes: getAllUserLikes(),
   233→        exportDate: new Date().toISOString()
   234→    }, null, 2);
   235→}
   236→
   237→/**
   238→ * Get like analytics for a specific post
   239→ */
   240→export function getPostLikeAnalytics(postSlug: string): {
   241→    count: number;
   242→    userLikes: UserLike[];
   243→    firstLikeDate: Date | null;
   244→    lastLikeDate: Date | null;
   245→} {
   246→    const count = getLikeCount(postSlug);
   247→    const userLikes = getAllUserLikes().filter(like => like.postSlug === postSlug);
   248→
   249→    let firstLikeDate = null;
   250→    let lastLikeDate = null;
   251→
   252→    if (userLikes.length > 0) {

   254→        firstLikeDate = new Date(Math.min(...timestamps));
   255→        lastLikeDate = new Date(Math.max(...timestamps));
   256→    }
   257→
   258→    return {
   259→        count,
   260→        userLikes,
   261→        firstLikeDate,
   262→        lastLikeDate
   263→    };
   264→}
